docs.title: Contribution Guide
docs.text: The KCEO Glossary is built from the EO community for the EO community. Your feedback and ideas are fundamental for the further development of this glossary. PR's and contributions of any kind are highly welcomed and encouraged. If you find yourself struggling with any of these steps, please reach out in the GitHub issues section. All you need to propose changes or add new terms is a GitHub account.

docs.title: Principles
docs.text:
• Avoid circle definitions at all cost
  • Multiple different definitions are allowed, but need to be separated
  • The files need to follow a certain structure to allow for proper parsing and tools to work (e.g. graph creation)
  • We use tags for dicussion status and term classes (base, core, controversial, high-impact)

docs.title: Tag System
docs.text:
We currently use the following tag system for:

  1. Discussion status:

    • term to add (only tagged in issue/discussion)
    • to be defined
    • to be discussed
    • to be approved
    • approved

  2. Class of term (from Strobl et al. 2024)

    • base term
    • core term
    • controversial term
    • high-impact term

docs.title: Editing Terms
docs.text: Editing existing terms is very simple. On each site in the glossary you will find a tiny edit icon on the top right, just next to the pages heading. If you click it you'll go directly to editing mode. Make the changes and create a PR.

docs.title: Adding Terms
docs.text:
If you are technical: You can either create a PR in the GitHub repository where we will review the request for certain formal aspects mentioned above under principles. If suitable, it will be merged. If it's a more controversial term, it will be discussed in the open where everyone can join the conversation.

If you are not technical, you can simply open an issue in the GitHub repository and ask us directly to add the term. The term can then be discussed just in the same way in the open. Have a look at the structure of the existing terms in the glossary and make sure to include the following sections:

  • Tags (facultative)
  • Definition
  • Notes (facultative)
  • Examples (facultative)
  • Sources

docs.title: Techincal Details
docs.text:
This glossary is built on mkdocs-material for simplicity. The source files are written in markdown and converted to html by mkdocs. If you intend on creating a PR with a new term, please see the _template.md file in the docs folder. A template for a term with two possible definitions looks like this: 

---
title: Test term
tags:
- base
---

# Test term

## 1 Definition

Definition_goes_here. 

### Notes
- here should be bullets
- like this

### Examples 
- this is also bullets
- like this

### Sources 
- KCEO (no link included, so no brackets)
- [Website](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thai_script) ( if you have web references, just add the term goes into square [] brackets and the url into () normal brackets

in case that there is more than one definition, just add three underscores to separate the definition, rest remains identical 

___

# Test term

## 2 Definition

Second_definition_goes_here. 

### Notes
- here should be bullets
- like this

### Examples 
- this is also bullets
- like this

### Sources 
- KCEO (no link included, so no brackets)
- [Website](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thai_script) ( if you have web references, just add the term goes into square [] brackets and the url into () normal brackets

References:

  1. Strobl, P. A., Woolliams, E. R., & Molch, K. (2024). Lost in Translation: The Need for Common Vocabularies and an Interoperable Thesaurus in Earth Observation Sciences. Surveys in Geophysics, 1-29.

docs.title: Contact
docs.text:
We are the Knowledge Centre on Earth Observation (European Commission - Joint Research Centre). Find us here: https://knowledge4policy.ec.europa.eu/earthobservation_en

  • For high-level inquiries contact: EC[minus]KCEO[ at ]ec.europa.eu
  • For contributions, questions, feedback etc. please use GitHub Issues

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The KCEO Glossary of Terms and Definitions serves as a reference for everyone involved in Earth Observation. We cover a wide range of terms, concepts, and definitions relevant to various EO disciplines such as remote sensing, satellite imagery, geospatial analysis, climate adaptation, and more. We strive to consolidate definitions where appropriate, while also acknowledging the necessity of their plurality when needed. Unlike many other online glossaries, our aim is to build an interactive and participative glossary for the EO community. As a living document, the KCEO Glossary of Terms and Definitions is in a constant state of evolution, continuously adapting while enabling full traceability.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Accuracy is the proximity of Measurement results to the accepted Value; precision is the degree to which repeated or reproducible measurements under unchanged conditions show the same results.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In essence, accuracy reflects how close measurements are to the accepted Value, while precision gauges the reliability and consistency of those measurements.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • BS ISO 5725-1

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data acquired on the same platform but not obtained from the main Sensor itself (usually provided as part of Level 0 Data). They have the primary purpose to serve the processing of main instrument Data (e.g. Position and velocity of platform).

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: This can be divided into data referred to as spacecraft ‘engineering’, ‘core housekeeping’ or ‘subsystem’ data obtained from other parts of the platform and includes parameters such as orbit position and velocity, attitude and its range of change, time, temperatures, pressures, jet firings, water dumps, internally produced magnet fields, and other environmental measurements. Ancillary refers to data that exist purely to serve the data processing.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• ESA/CEOS?, modified
  • EO Data Stewardship Glossary)

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Data other than instrument measurements, originating in the instrument itself or from the satellite, required to perform processing of the Data. They include orbit Data, attitude Data, time Information, and spacecraft engineering Data, Calibration Data, Data quality Information, and Data from other instruments or earth system models.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS-ARD PFS template 20220302

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: one of the Earth spheres consisting predominantly of matter processed by humans such as construction wood, bricks, concrete, asphalt, glass or plastics

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Stores data products, guaranteeing their preservation for future use

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • This function includes all operations to identify, store and retrieve the data and ensure their integrity.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The zone in 2D or 3D for which the Information or Data is requested. It can be discontinuous in space, in other words it can consist in the union of many separate zones (e.g., Natural Reserves in Africa, Urban environments, etc.). The attribute indicates a request for spatially complete Data within the AOI zone(s).

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Type Entry format example Valid units Geographical/administrative identifier NUTS3, LAU, Natura 2000 site unitless

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: the layer of gases, commonly known as air, including suspended liquid and solid particles known as aerosols (incl. dust, clouds, snow and ice).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data, which enhance processing, and utilization of main Sensor Data. The auxiliary Data are usually not captured by the same Data collection Process or on the same platform as the main Sensor Data. Examples are e.g. meteorological Data received from ECWMF/Met or DEMs. Offices. Auxiliary Data help in Data processing, but are also Data sets in their own right.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• ESA/CEOS?, modified
  • ENMAP Glossary of Terms, https://www.enmap.org/Data/doc/EnMAP_Terms.pdf, 20210624
  • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Data required to perform processing of Sensor Data which is not obtained from the Sensor itself. Include: (a) Data provided by the spacecraft (e.g. orbit Position and velocity, attitude, instrument house-keeping Data, on-board time), (b) Data not available from on-board sources.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: For EnMAP, this includes (a) Orbit files, attitude files, Calibration Data, instrument house-keeping Data, (b) atmospheric parameters, Reference images.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• ENMAP Glossary of Terms, https://www.enmap.org/Data/doc/EnMAP_Terms.pdf, 20210624
  • EO Data Stewardship Glossary)

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: The Data required for instrument processing, which does not originate in the instrument itself or from the satellite. Some auxiliary Data will be generated in the ground segment, whilst other Data will be provided from external sources.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS-ARD PFS template 20220302

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A general practice of making copies of current baseline and derived products of EO Collections, in specified time intervals, and storing those copies in a manner that will not affect the data if the primary distribution environment is compromised.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • The emphasis is on the ability to retrieve a copy of the entire EO Collection on demand if the original data is lost or compromised.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A single wavelength Value within the sensitivity interval of a spectroradiometric Sensor which represents the respective band. It could be either the mean, the median, the maximum sensitivity, or any other reasonable Value chosen to be representative.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 0.545 μm micrometre (μm), millimetre (mm), centimetre (cm)

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The Reference Period, time or measure against which the Information is assessed or compared

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Source data that has been processed to a common set of requirements and organised into a form that allows immediate analysis and interoperability through time and with other collections.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The masses of living organisms, such as vegetation and animals, including dead but still connected parts such as roots, trunks or branches.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: An organization's readiness to continue functioning during times of disruption.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The Process of quantitatively defining a system’s (e.g. a Sensor or Model’s) response to known, controlled inputs produced for example by references. In Remote Sensing, it implies the collection of pre-flight and in-flight calibration measurements and in-situ Data that is to be used in the Data calibration processing routine.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Provides the discovery of information to the user on which EO products can be obtained.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: • A 'Product Catalogue' can organise products and collections with varying access level depending on product and user type.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Spatial, spatio-temporal zone or temporal unit of geometry with dimensionality greater than 0, associated with a zone.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Cells are the unit of geometry in a DGGS, and the geometry of the region of space-time occupied by a zone is a cell.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Distinguishing Feature

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• A characteristic can be inherent or assigned.
  • A characteristic can be qualitative or quantitative.
  • There are various classes of characteristics, such as the following:
  • physical (e.g. mechanical, electrical, chemical, biological);
  • sensory (e.g. relating to smell, touch, taste, sight, hearing);
  • behavioural (e.g. courtesy, honesty, veracity);
  • temporal (e.g. punctuality, reliability, availability);
  • ergonomic (e.g. physiological characteristic or related to human safety);
  • functional (e.g. maximum speed of an aircraft).

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Abstraction of a Property of an Object or of a set of objects.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Characteristics are used for describing Concepts.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 1087-1:2000, 3.2.4; ISO 19146:2010(E); https://www.iso.org/standard/20057.html

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The nomenclature used to classify Information into categorical thematic classes (e.g., EUNIS, MAES ecosystems, Corine Land Cover, LCCS).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The levels in a hierarchical Classification System.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A climate projection is the simulated response of the climate system to a scenario of future emission or concentration of greenhouse gases (GHGs) and aerosols, generally derived using climate models. Climate projections are distinguished from climate predictions by their dependence on the emission/concentration/radiative forcing scenario used, which is in turn based on assumptions concerning, for example, future socioeconomic and technological developments that may or may not be realized.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • IPCC

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A group of products that have been processed using a consistent radiometric calibration, geometric registration base, data / metadata format, and version of processing algorithms.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Minor revisions to a relatively small number of products within a collection for the purpose of correcting errors and maintaining consistent quality.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A new and improved major version of all products within a collection due to comprehensive reprocessing.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The probability that the Quantity lies in the interval, conditioned on the measuring or modelling assumptions.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: Contribution Guide
docs.text: The KCEO Glossary is built from the EO community for the EO community. Your feedback and ideas are fundamental for the further development of this glossary. PR's and contributions of any kind are highly welcomed and encouraged. If you find yourself struggling with any of these steps, please reach out in the GitHub issues section. All you need to propose changes or add new terms is a GitHub account.

docs.title: Principles
docs.text:
• Avoid circle definitions at all cost
  • Multiple different definitions are allowed, but need to be separated
  • The files need to follow a certain structure to allow for proper parsing and tools to work (e.g. graph creation)
  • We use tags for dicussion status and term classes (base, core, controversial, high-impact)

docs.title: Tag System
docs.text:
We currently use the following tag system for:

  1. Discussion status:

    • term to add (only tagged in issue/discussion)
    • to be defined
    • to be discussed
    • to be approved
    • approved

  2. Class of term (from Strobl et al. 2024)

    • base term
    • core term
    • controversial term
    • high-impact term

docs.title: Editing Terms
docs.text: Editing existing terms is very simple. On each site in the glossary you will find a tiny edit icon on the top right, just next to the pages heading. If you click it you'll go directly to editing mode. Make the changes and create a PR.

docs.title: Adding Terms
docs.text:
If you are technical: You can either create a PR in the GitHub repository where we will review the request for certain formal aspects mentioned above under principles. If suitable, it will be merged. If it's a more controversial term, it will be discussed in the open where everyone can join the conversation.

If you are not technical, you can simply open an issue in the GitHub repository and ask us directly to add the term. The term can then be discussed just in the same way in the open. Have a look at the structure of the existing terms in the glossary and make sure to include the following sections:

  • Tags (facultative)
  • Definition
  • Notes (facultative)
  • Examples (facultative)
  • Sources

docs.title: Techincal Details
docs.text:
This glossary is built on mkdocs-material for simplicity. The source files are written in markdown and converted to html by mkdocs. If you intend on creating a PR with a new term, please see the _template.md file in the docs folder. A template for a term with two possible definitions looks like this: 

---
title: Test term
tags:
- base
---

# Test term

## 1 Definition

Definition_goes_here. 

### Notes
- here should be bullets
- like this

### Examples 
- this is also bullets
- like this

### Sources 
- KCEO (no link included, so no brackets)
- [Website](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thai_script) ( if you have web [references](../reference), just add the term goes into square [] brackets and the url into () normal brackets

in case that there is more than one definition, just add three underscores to separate the definition, rest remains identical 

___

# Test term

## 2 Definition

Second_definition_goes_here. 

### Notes
- here should be bullets
- like this

### Examples 
- this is also bullets
- like this

### Sources 
- KCEO (no link included, so no brackets)
- [Website](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thai_script) ( if you have web [references](../reference), just add the term goes into square [] brackets and the url into () normal brackets

References:

  1. Strobl, P. A., Woolliams, E. R., & Molch, K. (2024). Lost in Translation: The Need for Common Vocabularies and an Interoperable Thesaurus in Earth Observation Sciences. Surveys in Geophysics, 1-29.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: An institutional body, an organisation or programme that provides reliable, trusted (authoritative?) EO Information and that has the financial resources to sustain the provision. It utilizes satellite Data, ground-based measurements, and other sources to generate accurate and timely Data products related to various aspects of the Earth's environment, such as land, Atmosphere, oceans, and climate.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: Coverage interval
docs.text: Synonyms: Coverage extent

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Refers to a range or a specific subset of values associated with a coverage dataset.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The masses of frozen water, such as sea ice, ice shields, glaciers, and snow.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Entity responsible for the safe custody, transport, storage of the data and implementation of business rules.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • See also Steward

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Value and possibly Uncertainty of a Trait of a specific Entity.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Data simply describe entities using certain traits and are not targeted at a particular use or audience.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Data can be categorised into: - factual (i.e. obtained by Observation) or fictional (obtained e.g. through modelling, estimating or assigning) - quantitative (continuous) or qualitative (categorical) - analogue or digital (list not exhaustive!)

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Scientific or technical measurements, values calculated therefrom, observations, or facts that can be represented by numbers, tables, graphs, models, text, or symbols which are used as a basis for reasoning and further calculation.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The service to disseminate Data

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Structured Data that is machine readable and can be automatically read and processed by a computer, such as HDF, NetCDF, CSV, JSON, XML, etc.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS Wiki

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A legal instrument by which a copyright holder may grant rights over the protected work. Data and content is open if it is subject to an explicitly-applied licence that conforms to the Open Definition. A range of standard open licenses are available, such as the Creative Commons CC-BY licence, which requires only attribution.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS Wiki

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Products and collections that have been superseded by new versions and are no longer available.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Decommissioned products are no longer supported i.e corrections will not be made, new data will not be added, support is not available.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Products and collections that have been superseded by a version and are still available, but whose use is discouraged since they will be decommissioned in the future.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Additionally processed from baseline or unenhanced mission data.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Generally are either a compilation of time-series data (e.g., all time, annual, monthly or seasonal summary data, > Level 3) or thematic versions of each individual data tile of baseline data
  • Derived products are citable via a Digital Object Identifier (DOI).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: To permanently and irrecoverably remove all copies of data held by an organization.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Non-negative interval Quantity of time equal to the difference between the final and initial instants of a time.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The duration is one of the base quantities in the International System of Quantities (ISQ) on which the International System of Units (SI) is based. The term “time” instead of “duration” is often used in this context and also for an infinitesimal duration.
  • For the term “duration”, expressions such as “time” or “time interval” are often used, but the term “time” is not recommended in this sense and the term “time interval” is deprecated in this sense to avoid confusion with the concept of “time interval”.
  • The exact duration of a time scale unit depends on the time scale used. For example, the durations of a year, month, week, day, hour or minute, may depend on when they occur [in a Gregorian calendar, a calendar month can have a duration of 28, 29, 30, or 31 days; in a 24-hour clock, a clock minute can have a duration of 59, 60, or 61 seconds, etc.]. Therefore, the exact duration can only be evaluated if the exact duration of each is known.
  • This definition is closely related to NOTE 1 of the terminological entry “duration” in IEC 60050-113:2011, 113–01–13.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time that an antenna beam spends on a target.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • in the context of radar sensing

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: science domain dealing with technologies and methods of collecting and analyzing observations about the different Earth spheres

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Earth Observation (EO) can be categorised by Location of the Sensor into space-borne, air-borne, sea-borne, ground-based, underwater and underground EO.
  • Earth Observation (EO) includes Remote Sensing, such as satellite imagery, as well as in-situ observations, e.g., with ground-based devices.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Modified GEO definition GEO (earthobservations.org)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text:
(indicative level 4 and beyond) represent a higher level of processing and integration that goes beyond basic Data processing. These outputs are often designed specifically for Policy or decision-making needs, and can be categorized into sub-categories:

  • Outputs from models/Model Integration involves using EO products as inputs in numerical models or combining them with other Data sources in modeling frameworks.
  • Indicator-Based Outputs: EO products are transformed through specialized algorithms (including statistical methods, machine learning, and pattern recognition) to create meaningful metrics based on spatio-temporal analysis.
  • Outputs from Reanalysis: involves merging EO products with other observations and models, creating consistent long-term records of past atmospheric, oceanic, and land surface conditions, and filling gaps through Data assimilation techniques.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: (indicative levels 2 and 3) are the direct output from standardized satellite Data processing chains, representing fundamental geophysical and biophysical variables. These products demonstrate direct Traceability to original satellite measurements through rigorous Calibration and Validation processes. The processing methodology prioritizes the conversion of raw Sensor Data into quantifiable physical measurements, maintaining strict adherence to standardized processing protocols and Validation requirements.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Soil moisture from microwave sensors
  • Forest canopy height from LiDAR Data

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Spheres dividing planet Earth into subsystems, which are collectives of (physical) matter sharing specific traits

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Atmosphere
  • Hydrosphere
  • Cryosphere
  • Biosphere
  • Lithosphere
  • Anthroposhere

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• Hugget, R., et al, 2024, DOI: 10.1177/03091333241275465
  • Guth, P., et al, 2021, https://doi.org/10.3390/rs13183581
  • Martin, Y.E, et al, 2012

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Something that has separate and distinct existence and objective or conceptual reality.

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: A government or business organization that is formed to conduct business or represent the government of the day.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: CEOS Entities include Working Groups, Virtual Constellations, etc.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Earth Observation Data generated by spaceborne missions or instruments owned by public or private organizations.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • See also Instrument data.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Expanded Uncertainty is the Standard Uncertainty multiplied by a coverage factor, k. The coverage factor is chosen to obtain a desired level of confidence. Most commonly a 95% Confidence interval is chosen. For a Gaussian distribution, this is achieved with a coverage factor k = 2. (Note that strictly this provides a 95.45% Confidence interval).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Abstraction of real-world phenomena

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • A feature may occur as a type or an instance.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A product that is not expected to be updated within an EO Collection.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In its production, all of the prerequisite auxiliary data were input.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The forecast Period.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Translation of one form of Location into another.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Geocoding usually refers to the translation of "address" or "intersection" to "direct Position." Many services providers also include a "reverse geocoding" interface to their geocoder, thus extending the definition of the service as a general translator of Location. Because routing services use internal Location encodings not usually available to others, a geocoder is an integral part of the internals of such a service.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 19133:2005; https://www.iso.org/standard/32551.html

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Geographic coordinate Reference system (CRS) that has a geodetic Reference frame and an ellipsoidal coordinate system.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Also known as geographic CRS.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data with implicit or explicit Reference to a Location relative to the Earth.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Geographic Information is also used as a term for Information concerning phenomena implicitly or explicitly associated with a Location relative to the Earth.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: (Regular) Grid based on a Geographic Coordinate Reference System (CRS).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Spatial Reference in the form of a label or code that identifies a Location.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: • “Spain” is an example of a label (country name); “SW1-3AD” is an example of a code (postcode).

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Geopositioning an Object using a Physical Sensor Model or a True Replacement Model.

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Determination of the geographic location of a >=2D feature(?).

docs.text: • ISO 19130-1:2018, 3.36 (‘geopositioning’), modified

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Information used to determine geographic Location.

docs.title: 1 Definition

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Modified from: ISO 19130-1:2018, 3.36

docs.title: Georectifying
docs.text: Synonyms: Orthorectifying

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Correcting for positional displacement with respect to the surface of the Earth.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Source: ISO 19115-2:2019, 3.11; ISO 19115-2:2009(E); https://www.iso.org/standard/67039.html, modified

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: The correction of sample locations to achieve some sort of geometric regularity, e.g., a regular 2D geographic grid.

docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Consisting of, derived from, or relating to Data that is directly linked to specific geographical locations.

• https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/geospatial
  • https://isotc211.geolexica.org/Concepts/202/, accessed 20221010

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: the masses of minerals that constitute planet Earth.

docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The smallest aggregation of data which is independently managed (i.e. described, inventoried, retrievable). Granules may be managed as logical granules and/or physical granules.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • See also product.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • NASA EarthData

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Network composed of two or more sets of curves in which the members of each set intersect the members of the other sets in an algorithmic way.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • The curves partition a space into grid cells.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The masses of liquid water, such as oceans, lakes, and rivers.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: impact is regarded long-term according to X. However, in the Horizon Europe Missions terminology, impact is regarded short-term.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Observations performed in the same Place where a Phenomenon occurs, normally without isolating it from other systems (its environment) or altering its pre-Observation state

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The main Characteristic of such observations is that distance has no or only negligible (within Uncertainty) influence on the Value of the Property observed. In-situ observations therefore often require either direct physical contact or small distances between a Sensor and the observed Phenomenon.
  • Observations not fulfilling these conditions are considered Remote Sensing

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The result of organisation, interpretation, categorisation, classification, or some other form of processing of Data attaching to it a certain meaning that can be understood by the addressee.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Information depends on Data and is targeted.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data specifically associated with the instrument, either because it was generated by the instrument or included in data packets identified with that instrument.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • These data consist of instrument science and engineering data, and possibly ancillary data. Instrument engineering data is produced by engineering sensor(s) of an instrument, used either for operating the instrument or for processing the science data generated by the instrument. Instrument science data is produced by the science sensor(s) of an instrument, usually constituting the basic reason for existence of an instrument.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Data created by an instrument including scientific measurements and any engineering or ancillary data which may be included in the data packets.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: Data produced and transmitted by the science and engineering sensors of an instrument, and, in the spacecraft environment, any additional data packaged with the instrument’s sensor data by virtue of services provided

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Laboratory observations are (usually) in-situ observations in which the Object or Phenomenon is isolated from other systems or altered in its ‘original’ conditions or environment.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • It's important to consider that laboratory observations are typically conducted in controlled conditions, allowing for isolation or alteration of the Object or Phenomenon from its natural environment or other systems.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Period between the end of sensing of a Phenomenon to the beginning of availability of a specific product

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ?

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Minimum time of interval between an Observation being tasked and being performed

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The solid, inanimate outer layer of the Geosphere. For the purposes of Earth Observation, the lithosphere is considered to include soils (‘pedosphere’)

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Particular Place referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• While a (geo)location identifies a geographic Place, it may also be associated with objects other than the Earth.
  • While location in principle covers 0- to 3-dimensional spatial geometries, it should not be used for 0- and 1-dimensional geometries (positions and paths)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Madrid
  • California

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 19112:2019, (E), 3.1.3, modified, note 2 added

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Indicate the agreement between the represented Location of an Object and the true Location.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The act of maintaining information in a correct and independently understandable form over the long term

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Long term refers to a period of time long enough to be concerned with the impact which changing technologies, including support for media and data formats, and changing user communities will have on the information being held in a repository.
  • See also preservation

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Particular Quantity subject to Measurement.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Step Process description (Raw) The complete and unaltered/unprocessed set of Data acquired by one or several sensors on a platform M/0 uncalibrated Unaltered/unprocessed Level 0 (main) Sensor Data annotated with processed Ancillary Data and supplemented by Auxiliary Data (including radiometric and geometric Calibration coefficients and geo-referencing parameters) allowing further processing to higher Levels. M/1 Sensor-calibrated Level M/0 Sensor Data which have been calibrated (ideally traceable to SI) and spatially aligned (co-located, eventually co-gridded) to represent at-Sensor measurements (Value and Uncertainty) in Sensor nominal spatiotemporal sampling, supplemented by appropriate anc M/2 target-calibrated Level M/1 Data processed to represent geophysical Property values (and uncertainties) for a specified target (Object, Feature of interest, e.g. surface reflectance, apparent temperature) derived from M/1 Sensor Data, as much as possible maintaining the sensors nominal spatial and temporal sampling (Observation preserving). M/3 homogenised Level M/1 or M/2 Data which have been generalised and integrated across one or several platforms and acquisitions to achieve an increased, more regular or in any other form enhanced spatial or temporal coverage in which states geophysical values agnostic of the originally acquiring Sensor and Observation condition and thus directly comparable. This homogenisation and fusion may include measurand re-Calibration to external standards and references including use of modelling, aggregation and interpolation. M/4 derived/infered Model output or results from analyses of Level M/3 (or lower level) Data i.e., attributes that might not be directly observable by the Sensor(s) but are derived from observations in combination with other external incl. non-observational Data using techniques like modelling or machine learning (AI).

From http://doi.org/10.2760/46796

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Observation of a Quantity.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • The Process of collecting a measurement is called measuring.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • GEOGlos (VIM ?, modified)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Uncertainty associated with the method of Measurement.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS Wiki adopted from JCGM GUM

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data about data, which provides an understanding of the content and utility of the product or collection.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Metadata may be used to select on data for a particular scientific investigation.
  • Metadata is intended as information describing significant aspects of a resource (Earth Observation space data in this context). They are created for the purposes of data search, discovery and access management and may exist at various levels, typically from data collection through to the individual variables of each product in a collection.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The area of the smallest Feature that is still represented on a map.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CGLS

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The width of the smallest linear Feature that is still represented on a map.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CGLS

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: An, often numeric, theoretical (or otherwise abstract) representation of an Entity intended to generate Data describing one or more of its traits (as a result of pre-set conditions).

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • The Process of generating Data using a model is called modelling.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data that is available for use with a specified (small and application dependent) latency, typically 3 hours for meteorological applications.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Entity with a well-defined boundary and identity that encapsulates state and behaviour.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO/IEC 19501:2005

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: act of determining the Value of a Property by interacting in a reproducible way with the Phenomenon using a Sensor

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• the result of an observation is a Value complemented by an Uncertainty, often itself being referred to as 'observation'
  • an observation (result) represents a Sample of the Phenomenon (otherwise it would be identical with the Phenomenon)

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Products or collections which have been superseded by later versions of a product or collection.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A line defined in an algorithmic way using at least two positions. (could be open ended) Alternative: A line connecting two positions in an algorithmic way. (limited by end points)

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • A path is a 1-dimensional Place

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Particular era or span of time.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Periods are intervals named with a Period identifier.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Temporal Reference in the for of a label or code that identifies a Period.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Period identifiers are the temporal equivalent of geographic identifiers as specified in ISO 19912

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Entity with at least one Property referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO, modified after Wikipedia and the Columbia Encyclopaedia 2008

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Part of any space referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A deliberate system of guidelines to guide decisions and achieve rational outcomes. A policy is a statement of intent and is implemented as a procedure or protocol. Policies are typically promulgated through official written documents.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A well-established concept, which is typically taught as the rational Model of Policy decision-making. It is an idealised view of the Policy Process.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ESA/CEOS?, modified

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Policy documents that represent the official written Reference for a given Policy.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The Process by which governments translate their political vision into programmes and actions to deliver 'outcomes' - desired change in the real world.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ESA/CEOS?, modified

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Policy milestones mark significant progress in addressing specific issues, or crucial decision points where significant choices are made. Concrete examples of Policy milestones are: Policy planning and proposing, impact assessment, implementation, or implementation cycles (e.g., Water Framework Directive, Marine Strategy Framework Directive), achievement of Policy objectives and Policy targets, evaluating evaluating and improvement of existing laws.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Desired Outcome that policymakers wish to achieve.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Specific level or rate set for the Policy objective.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Place referenced by a single set of coordinates within a coordinate Reference system.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Opposite to (previous) ISO definition, position shall be used only for 0-dimensional primitives (points).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 19133:2005, modified to cover only points, also called ‘direct position’

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Processes and operations used to ensure data technical and intellectual survival through time.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• It grants data integrity, its discoverability and accessibility, and facilitates its (re)-use in the long term.
  • Preservation is one of the tasks of data curation.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A series of activities that interact to produce a result.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: A process may occur once-only or be recurrent or periodic.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Wikipedia

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Electronic data package distributable to users; content is derived from instrument data via processing involving ancillary and auxiliary data.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Products may be accompanied by metadata and browse images.
  • A product may be part of a collection – a distinction useful for archiving and cataloguing purposes.
  • The term product may be used to denote a product type, such as e.g. ENVISAT_ASAR_L1B_PRI data products.
  • End users may distinguish between (input, "raw") data and products, i.e., the derived geophysical parameters.
  • See also granule.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: observable Trait

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Products in a research and development phase not yet been published into a standardized collection.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A quality indicator shall provide sufficient Information to allow all users to readily evaluate the “fitness for purpose” of the Data or derived product. A Quality Indicator may be a number, set of numbers, graph, Uncertainty budget, or a simple “flag”.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS Wiki

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Property having a magnitude that can be expressed as a number from a continuous and contiguous range and a Reference.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO/IEC Guide 99:2007, 1.1, modified – Notes omitted

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Property whose instances can be compared by ratio or only by order.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • gEOGlos(VIM4 Notes omitted)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A Phenomenon whose values for specific properties are known and understood with an Uncertainty significantly lower (quantify?) than that of the Observation with which it is compared.

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: A sort of Data acquired with an Uncertainty significantly lower (quantify?) than that of the Data it is being compared with.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • VIM?, modified

docs.title: Remote Sensing
docs.text: Synonyms: Remote Observation

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: type of Observation performed at a significant distance from a Phenomenon.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• ‘Significant’ in this context means that the distance has, or may have, a non-negligible impact on the Value of the Property observed.
  • The effect of the distance on the acquired Data is the main distinction criterion between ‘remote’ and ‘in-situ’ observations.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Enables other researchers to conduct an independent study with different Data and similar but not identical methods, yet arriving at results that confirm the original study’s hypothesis.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Craglia, M., ei al,. (2018).

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The quality or Characteristic of a Measurement or Observation to accurately represent a specific geographic Location, time Period, or environmental condition.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • WIGOS metadata standard defines representativeness as the extent of the region around the Observation of which it is representative.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Is concerned with the validity of the results of that particular study, i.e., the possibility of readers to check whether results have been manipulated, by reproducing exactly the same study using the same Data and methods.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Ostermann and Granell (2015)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Subset of one or more entities.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The subset may be spatial, temporal, spectral, or in any other dimension or Trait.
  • The subset is contiguous, i.e. it does not consist of more than one discontinuous interval along any dimension.
  • The Process of obtaining a sample is called sampling.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A (technical?) device or instrument suited (through physical/chemical interaction) to measure one or more properties of a Phenomenon and thus collect factual/objective Data.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Sensing is therefore a synonym for Observation (the Process).
  • As by their definition, sensors perform sampling.
  • Sensors used to obtain measurements must be calibrated and provide uncertainties.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data required for production of an EO Collection (e.g., unenhanced satellite mission data) as well as further processed Level-1 data (precision geometrically and radiometrically corrected radiance at the sensor), or any other pre-processed format that suppliers are providing access to that meets program requirements.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The presence or absence of gaps, which are missing values in an otherwise continuous spatial Data series.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: • surface soil moisture retrieved from microwave satellite sensors may present gaps in mountainous terrains.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The spatial statistical properties of the Data depend only on the underlaying physical processes and don’t depend on other factors such as fusing different products or sensors. Also, the validity of the assumptions of the procedure to produce Information holds true across the whole spatial range.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text:
The zone or region of space described by a Geographic Identifier in the form of a label or code, or by a bounding box. It consists in the maximum extent (the spatial boundary or limits) within which the User is requesting Data.

The attribute represents the maximum spatial extent of the AOI, and in case the AOI is made of many discontinuous zones then it represents the maximum extent of the union of all the zones.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • WIGOS metadata standard defines it as the typical spatial georeferenced volume covered by the observations

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: • if a User is requesting Information about degradation of African protected sites, then the AOIs are the protected sites, and the spatial extent is the African continent.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Adapted from ISO 19170-1:2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The smallest spatial Object of interest that may be used for reporting and for which the Information should be aggregated.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • WIGOS 2019 use ‘spatial reporting interval’ probably assuming the observations are reported on a Grid with regular spacing/intervals.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Part of the electromagnetic spectrum of specific wavelengths. In Remote Sensing usually described by central wavelength and bandwidth.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The range of the Spectral band.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Measure of the ability to resolve features in the electromagnetic spectrum.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The maximum acceptable change in Uncertainty per decade.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • GCOS uses bias or systematic errors instead of Uncertainty

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • modified from GCOS 2022

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Standard Uncertainty describes the standard deviation of the probability distribution describing the spread of possible values in quantitative/continuous [Data].

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Entity responsible for the safe custody, transport, storage of the data and implementation of business rules.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • See also Custodian

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • WGISS Shared Collection Lifecycle Management Principles for Earth Observation Data

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: It indicates that the temporal statistical properties of the Sample depend only on the underlying physical processes and don’t depend on other factors such as fusing different products or sensors.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The Period during which Data was collected, observations were made, or for which the Model was run.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• In W3C is the definition of temporal coverage
  • Time Period covered by a series of observations inclusive of the specified date/time indications (Measurement history). Defined based on the beginning and end dates of observations.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: • WIGOS Metadata

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • adapted from W3C

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time Period used for reporting and for which the Information should be aggregated from the native Temporal Resolution.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1 s, 2 h, 1 d second, hour, day, month, year

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • modified WIGOS Metadata Standard 2019

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The Observation or Model output representing regular intervals and specifying the length of the interval that determines the smallest event or Process that can be resolved (e.g., the Period between observations, the time steps in a Model).

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • WIGOS 2019 distinguishes between sampling time Period, as the Period over which a Measurement is taken, and temporal sampling interval as the time Period between the beginning of consecutive sampling periods. Temporal resolution in this Glossary is equivalent to sampling time Period as used by WIGOS.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1 s, 2 h, 1 m second, hour, day, month, year

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The interval between successive observations.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• In Remote Sensing it is also called repeat cycle.
  • More generally it is known as temporal sampling interval.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1 s, 2 h second, hour, day, month, year

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The level of categorical detail of Information expressed by the number of classes.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CGLS

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Uncertainty associated with the method of classification.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Typically, it is computed from the error matrix.
  • For a review of classification Uncertainty metrics, consult Ye et al. 2018.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time of the day that the variable or parameter is observed or simulated by a Model.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In Remote Sensing it is also known as time of overpass.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Type Entry format example Valid unit timestamp 18:00 h (0-24) Hours timerange 18:00 – 20:00 h Hours

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time of the year that the variable is observed or simulated by a Model.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Type Entry format example Valid unit timestamp m/d Not Applicable timerange m/d - m/d Not Applicable

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text:
The Period between the moment of requesting Information to the moment of availability of Information.

  • Near Real-Time (NRT): delivered less than 3 hours after requesting Information
  • Slow-Time Critical (STC): delivered within 48 hours after requesting Information
  • Non-Time Critical (NTC): typically delivered within 1 month after requesting Information

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• In some context also known as delivery time.
  • C3S URDB describes timeliness as “the ability of the publish/subscribe middleware to provide the expected service within known time bounds”

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Adapted from ESA S3 User Guide

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Property of a Measurement result whereby the result can be related to a Reference through a documented unbroken chain of calibrations each contributing to the Measurement uncertainty.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • https://www.isobudgets.com/Measurement-traceability-complying-iso-17025-requirements/

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A quality or Characteristic belonging to an Entity and referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Traits can be objective (inherent?) in which case they are also observable and called properties. Traits which are not observable (directly or indirectly) need to be assigned.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Based on ISO 19143:2010, 4.21, ISO/IEC 2382:2015, 2121440, significantly modified, Note 1 added

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A parameter, associated with the result of a Measurement, that characterises the dispersion of the values that could reasonably be attributed to the Measurand.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • GUM

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Non-negative parameter, associated with Data, which characterizes the dispersion of the values of a [Trait ]that could reasonably be attributed to a Phenomenon [by means of sensing or modelling].

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• In case of quantitative(continuous) Data the uncertainty may be, for example, a standard deviation (or a given multiple of it), or the half-width of an interval having a stated level of confidence. (see e.g. standard and Expanded uncertainty)
  • For qualitative (categorical?) Data uncertainty may be, for example, expressed by commission and omission (‘confusion matrix’) or overall errors.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • modified from GUM, VIM4 :3.1, FIDUCEO, Notes added

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: Uncertainty is a measure of the spread of the distribution of possible values.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • FIDUCEO Glossary, VIM?, modified

docs.title: 4 Definition
docs.text: Parameter, associated with the result of Measurement, that characterizes the dispersion of values that could reasonably be attributed to the Measurand.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • When the quality of Accuracy or precision of measured values, such as coordinates, is to be characterized quantitatively, the quality parameter is an estimate of the uncertainty of the Measurement results. Because Accuracy is a qualitative concept, one should not use it quantitatively, that is associate numbers with it; numbers should be associated with measures of uncertainty instead.

docs.title: 5 Definition
docs.text: Parameter characterizing the dispersion of the values being attributed to a Measurand, based on the Information used.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • VIM4: 3.1

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The frequency at which the product is available to users.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Also known in product catalogues as dissemination frequency

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: In the context of the KCEO, an Entity (person, organization, institution, etc.) that is requesting Data or Information with certain characteristics described by needs and/or requirements.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: External person, institution or system that consumes provided services.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: Includes Data Access or Science and Service Exploitation Platforms provided by a payload data ground segment.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EO Data Stewardship Glossary)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Set of all the components of an interactive system that provide Information and controls for the User to accomplish specific tasks with the interactive system.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Process of assessing, by independent means, the quality of the Data products derived from the system outputs.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In this part of ISO 19159, the term validation is used in a limited sense and only relates to the validation of Calibration Data in order to control their change over time.

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Validation aims to verify that the specified requirements are achieved or compliant. This involves comparing mission products with representative Reference Data, considering various Observation conditions, ensuring the quality and Traceability of the Reference Data used.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In this part of ISO 19159, the term validation is used in a limited sense and only relates to the validation of Calibration Data in order to control their change over time.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • BIPM; QA4EO; ESA ?, modified

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: The assurance that a product, service, or system meets the needs of the customer and other identified stakeholders. It often involves acceptance and suitability with external customers.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In this part of ISO 19159, the term validation is used in a limited sense and only relates to the validation of Calibration Data in order to control their change over time.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EU-US Land Imaging EO Collaboration

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: element of a type domain

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• A value may consider a possible state of an Object within a class or type (domain).

  • A Data value is an instance of a Data type, a value without identity

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Provision of objective evidence that a given item fulfils specified requirements.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• When applicable, Measurement uncertainty should be taken into consideration.
  • The item may be, e.g. a Process, Measurement procedure, material, compound, or measuring system.
  • The specified requirements may be, e.g. that a manufacturer's specifications are met.
  • Verification should not be confused with Calibration. Not every verification is a Validation.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO/IEC Guide 99:2007, 2.44

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: The evaluation of whether or not a product, service, or system complies with a regulation requirement, specification, or imposed condition. It is often an internal Process.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EU-US Land Imaging EO Collaboration

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: Verification serves as a means to evaluate the reliability of the Data in the absence of a Reference dataset, allowing for an assessment of its standalone performance. It involves confirming the consistency and internal coherence of the Data without direct comparison to external Reference sources.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A method of working with collections, similar to the version control systems used in traditional software development but optimized to allow better processing of data and collaboration in the context of data analytics, research, and any other form of data analysis.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Wikipedia

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Levels of a vertical discretization. Examples may be pressure levels in an atmospheric Model reanalysis or height levels in a forest biomass EO product.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1, 5, 10 meter; 1000, 850, 500 hPa meter, hPa, unitless

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.text: For easy integrating in mkdocs, create a standalone html from index.html and bundle.js and copy & paste it to sigmajs.md.
